Introduction to PHP
PHP, an acronym for Hypertext Preprocessor, is a web development scripting language, and it's actually present in most of the internet websites! It is estimated that almost 80% of all known websites online have PHP somewhere in their source code. If you want to know more about PHP, here is some information to get started by:

History

PHP was created sometime in the Fall of 1994 by Danish-Canadian programmer Rasmus Lerdorf, and he initially used what would become PHP to track visits to his online resume! Because of that, PHP initially stood for “Personal Home Page tools.” It's worth noting that PHP is not a programming language, but rather a scripting language, just like Python, JavaScript, Bash, and others.

Scripting languages differ from programming languages in that they are interpreted, instead of compiled. Scripting languages are, therefore, slower than compiled languages (Java, C++). Another disadvantage of scripting languages is that they always need to be interpreted/run inside another program. This is why PHP code often appears within HTML code, enclosed between the <?php and ?> tags.1

PHP is typically used on websites to generate web page content dynamically, retrieving information from a database and sending it back to the web server, for instance. Let’s analyze two snippets of PHP code (inside HTML code), with different complexity levels. Take a look: 

<!DOCTYPE HTML>
<html>
        <body> 
            <h1> Best Movies of 2023 </h1>
            <?php echo "1. The Hunger Games"; ?> 
        </body>
</html>

In this snippet of HTML code, the built-in function 'echo' is used to write to the page directly. The output of this code is, therefore: 

Best Movies of 2023
1. The Hunger Games

Let's now look at a more complex example of PHP code (modified from W3Schools): 

<?php 
$servername = "localhost"; 
$username = "Wendy"; 
$password = "password"; 
$connection = new mysqli($servername, $username, $password); 
                            
$connection = mysqli_connect($servername, $username, $password); 
if (!$connection) { 
    die("Connection failed: " . mysqli_connect_error()); 
} 
echo "Connected successfully"; 
?>

The PHP code above could be used for selecting and connecting to a MySQL database, in between HTML code, for example! We can notice through this example that PHP variables are declared by a dollar sign $. We also notice the built-in function 'die', used to print a message and exit from the current PHP script immediately. Now that you have been exposed to PHP, maybe you can consider taking a Wellesley course that involves PHP!

Wellesley Specific Information

In the past, only CS304, our Databases with Interfaces course, included any PHP. In more recent years, however, no computer science course at Wellesley teaches PHP anymore, including 304. Therefore, if you want to get more experience with PHP at Wellesley, we recommend reaching out to faculty such as Scott Anderson (scott.anderson@wellesley.edu) and ask for old 304 course materials, from when PHP was still part of the curriculum!

Best IDEs

There are a couple of good IDEs to write and edit PHP scripts, some of them offering syntax check, debugging tools, and smart code completion. Here are some:

  • Visual Studio Code: Free to download, good-old VS Code!
  • PHPStorm: Perhaps the best PHP development tool, but requires paying!

Further Reading and Practice

The best way to learn more about PHP is by (1) taking a course that goes over it at Wellesley, or (2) doing your own research/project and learning online! If you want to see more PHP code examples, a very good website I recommend is java2s.com's PHP source code examples ✨ organized by topic ✨.

I hope you feel more comfortable with PHP after reading this. Now go and learn more!

With love,
Maria Vitoria Moura Cabrera '25
